Award.AwardTitle: Universality and Beyond for Atoms with Large Scattering Length
Award.AbstractNarration:
Atoms that interact strongly at low energy exhibit universal behavior that does not depend on details of atomic physics. The development of methods for trapping atoms, cooling them to ultralow temperatures, and manipulating their interaction strengths has made universality of practical importance for controlling atoms and molecules. The ultimate goal of this project is to predict the behavior of few-body and many-body systems consisting of strongly-interacting ultracold atoms and the weakly-bound molecules formed by these atoms. Although this project is focussed primarily on ultracold atoms, universality ensures that the results will also be applicable to other fields of science, including nuclear physics, high energy physics, condensed matter physics, and astrophysics.

This award will be used primarily to support a graduate student who will be working on this research project. The training received by the graduate student in carrying out the research will contribute to the building of a diverse scientific workforce. The mix of analytical and numerical computation required by this project is excellent preparation for both academic and industrial research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eric Braaten completed a research project on ``universal'' aspects of ultracold atoms with
large scattering lengths.  This work has broader impacts beyond atomic physics, because the 
universal aspects apply equally well to particles with short-range interactions in other 
subfields of physics, even if their length scales and energy scales differ dramatically from 
atomic scales.  The elucidation of universal aspects of few-body physics and many-body 
physics has been one of the major themes in cold atom physics in the last decade.

Braaten made several significant advances in the course of this research project.
(a) Braaten made a breakthrough in calculating transition rates from an oscillating magnetic
field, which makes the interactions between atoms oscillate in strength.  He used it to derive 
simple formulas for the rate for associating atoms into diatomic molecules in a thermal gas 
of atoms.
(b) The first experiments on the unitary Bose gas, which consists of bosonic atoms whose 
interactions are infinitely strong, were carried out by a group at JILA in 2014.  Braaten 
showed that their measurements of the momentum distribution reveal evidence of 
log-periodic oscillations associated with three-atom interactions.
(c) The simplest universal properties of atoms correspond to taking the limit as the range of 
the interactions between atoms goes to zero.  Systematic corrections can be obtained by 
expanding in powers of the range.  Braaten deduced simpler expressions for the first-order
range corrections for bosonic atoms that will make it easier to apply them to cold atom 
experiments.
(d) Braaten also figured out how deeply inelastic reactions can be taken into account in an 
effective field theory for ultracold atoms through the Lindblad equation for the density matrix.

Braaten has provided training for graduate students in theoretical physics applied to 
ultracold atoms.  Christian Langmack completed his thesis research and received his PhD
degree in 2013.  Hudson Smith has completed his thesis research and is in the process of 
writing his thesis.  Another student Abhishek Mohapatra is also carrying out research 
under Braaten's supervison.
